node.title: Here’s why jury selection took so long.
node.alt: Demonstrators with the nonprofit organization Transformative Justice Coalition gathered in Brunswick, Ga., late last month as the jury was selected, a grueling process that lasted two and a half weeks.
node.description: Selecting an impartial jury from a small town where everyone knows everyone meant filtering through hundreds of candidates.
node.content: ["Jury selection in the trial of the three men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery took two and a half weeks, an extraordinarily long process made difficult by the high-profile nature of the case.", "The jury was chosen from Glynn County, Ga., which has a population of about 84,500. Court officials cast a wide net, setting up an intake center at a gymnasium in a local park, where hundreds of potential jurors were given an initial screening. Eventually, a pool of 65 was assembled, to be whittled to 12 jurors and four alternates.", "Annie Deets, a public defender and adjunct law professor at Georgia State and Emory Universities, said she had seen jury selection completed in as little as a day or two and, in some cases, up to a week. The length of the process in the Arbery case, she said, was a rarity.", "The task of finding an impartial jury for a case involving three separate defendants was already difficult \u2014 and the challenges were compounded by the fact that Mr. Arbery\u2019s killing was among the most explosive murder cases in South Georgia in decades. Many potential jurors said they had viewed the video of Mr. Arbery\u2019s fatal encounter taken by one of the defendants.", "\u201cWhen you have a case that\u2019s high profile and been in the media so much, people make ideas based off snippets and pieces of information,\u201d Ms. Deets said. \u201cBut there\u2019s a wealth of information known to the prosecution that the public doesn\u2019t know about.\u201d", "This becomes even more challenging when one considers the court system\u2019s desire to find a local jury, consisting of each defendant\u2019s peers.", "\u201cIn a small community, people know a lot of people involved in the case,\u201d Ms. Deets said. \u201cThat really close-knit web of relationships complicates the process even further.\u201d"]
